snippet.textDisplay:
Really good game however a  couple of flaws I've found.
1. It's linear when instanced outside the world map.  
2. There is no map or even a compass in the instances which is a bad design choice
3. There should be a way to save like 3 builds with attributes, and skills weapons and pictos.  I have no idea why they don't have like 3 slots to save set ups, you could still be required to use the rebuild things to reset attributes, but if you want to change up a build it takes forever or if you want to switch a characters build it takes forever and there is no reason for that whatsoever.

snippet.textDisplay: I cannot enjoy this game.  I have turned the difficulty down to story, and it's still punishing.  How do y'all love this game so much?! The window for parrying and dodging is microscopic, and entirely guesswork unless you know what's coming.  The game does not teach anything as far as the system goes.  I'm just bumbling through trying to figure shit out, all the while getting trampled by enemies.  I'd actually say this is worse than a souls game because there's no option to evade in a turn based game.   You just have to stand there and hope you don't die.  I swear I'd return this shit if I could.  I don't mind a challenging game, but holy shit, this isn't a game for me, this is just a slap in the face followed by pointing and laughing while I'm just wanting to enjoy the story.

snippet.textDisplay:
4:49 It's explained that Pictos require 4 victories to fully activate (make learnable through Lumina).  But you're able to see how many victories a Picto has because it draws the diamond around the icon.  Fully active Pictos will have the full diamond and the color of it's icon is bright.  A Picto with no victories has a gray diamond and a gray icon.  A Picto in between will have a dim icon and 1 to 3 bars of its diamond.
8:40 In the character sheet you can see what you're current Pictos would cost as Lumina.  They are always at the top of the Lumina list. In this case Energy Master is 40, Shortcut is 5. So if you use expensive Pictos you can minimize Lumina, or distribute it elsewhere.  The stats on Pictos also need to be considered, so the Lumina cost is only part of the equation.
Menu: You can also change Run to a toggle, so you click the right trigger rather than needing to hold it.  The left trigger to Aim also can be a toggle rather than a hold.
2:49 I don't know if the attack flub vs ok vs perfect was truly explained or not, but the QTE (quick time event) when you attack will show a diamond and marker will advance around it.  If you click in a black section it will flub the attack, doing less hits.  If you click in the white area  it will be a good average hit.  If you click in the gold section it will "perfect" and do more hits, more damage, or more benefit for buffs. For example, when a skill says add 0-2 AP it will add 0 for a flub, 1 for a good, or 2 for a perfect.

snippet.textDisplay:
A tip on parrying. don’t look at your character when parrying. Some of their parry animations could throw you off especially when an enemy has quick attacks. Sometimes you’d be mid parry and the enemy starts attacking again, and your character is still up in the air 😂. Enemies have either visual cues or audio cues (some have both, some have just either) on when’s the best time to parry. 

Also, play the game but don’t get too stuck doing side content as you might overlevel yourself to the point where you won’t get to see the enemy’s other animations or hear their voicelines 😂
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: One thing to note it that, as far as I have seen, the recovery percentage of abilities don't seem to be working properly.  I've seen Lunes healing light which is supposed to be between 30-50% only heal 272 on a character with over 1000 hp and grim harvest from Sciel that's ONLY supposed to heal for 30% healing 580 on a character with only 666.  (Which happens to be Sciel herself in case your thinking it's based on the casters HP which obviously isn't the case either)  I kept roulette unequipped to test this as well as trying on easier difficulty.  So either I'm missing something important with how heals work in this game or those percentages are completely wrong or misleading.

snippet.textDisplay: VERY IMPORTANT.   If you are playing this on ps5/4  make sure that you upload your saved game to the cloud every time you are going to stop playing.  i lost 10 hours of gameplay because the game randomly reverted to my lvl 1 saved file from the playstation cloud.    gotta say ,  it sucked.   thankfully  i was able to get back to the same spot in about a 3rd the time.    you'll do much better from the start again because you know how to parry ect.

snippet.textDisplay:
For attributes, I've found that vitality, agility, and luck are the core ones to focus on pre act 3. Having a decent investment in vitality (about 20 points) will be enough to give you a nice damage cushion. After 20 points, HP gains fall off. Agility is super important, as getting more turns/making sure enemies do not get more turns is vital. 45-50 points is the optimal investment pre act 3. Luck is great for crits. 15 points gives you a 9% crit chance which is great. 35 will get you a 15% crit chance. Gains fall off after 35 luck, so that is where I'd stop. Might is where you should dump all the extra points.

Act 3 is where everything changes. Pictos start granting huge stat buffs and this is where most of your stats will come from. All of my defense comes from the little that agility gives me and the pictos I have equipped. At this point, spec your build around pictos and respec your stats to your choice of final weapon's damage scaling stats.

Luck is great for crits. 15 points gives you a 9% crit chance which is great. 35 will get you a 15% crit chance. Gains fall off after 35 luck, so that is where I'd stop. Might is where you should dump all the extra points.

Act 3 is where everything changes. Pictos start granting huge stat buffs and this is where most of your stats will come from. All of my defense comes from the little that agility gives me and the pictos I have equipped. At this point, spec your build around pictos and respec your stats to your choice of final weapon's damage scaling stats.

snippet.textDisplay: if you have played lies of p, the parry timing is similar to that game and just like that game don't be afraid to dodge instead. Sometimes I parry then dodge.  Also the longer you stay alive the more damage you will do. Lets take the mime enemies for example: at first you will only be doing 12 to 50 damage if you fight them at level 10, but if you can survive and stack your effects then your damage will go up to 500 or 1000 with the same level characters.  This means that even at low levels as long as you can parry and dodge reliably then you will be able to get big damage.

snippet.textDisplay:
Everyone says you need to parry when you are getting hit. I have the exact opposite experience, i always need to parry WAY before the attack starts, and then it works. For example the "dips sword into blood" attack i can parry every time, but i learnt to press parry when the sword didn't even start to attack, it's going backwards. If i press it later, i WILL fail.
Same for a lot of the huge enemies jumps, i need to parry way BEFORE it even starts to come down. 
So really, kind of the opposite what it says in the video. Maybe it's different on PC and consoles?

snippet.textDisplay:
Sorry, but I disagree with a bunch of these tips (I'm currently at Act 3)
1. You don't need to waste precious resources on upgrading multiple weapons on the same character to get type advantage because usually skills don't depend on the weapon's type
2. Don't always parry. If you're trying to learn patterns, dodge first and then try to parry. There are also some enemies with very high damage and hard to parry, and so parrying them for some extra bit of damage is just not worth it.
3. You don't need Lune's revive if you got a few revive items. If you characters die too much you're likely to loose anyway even with infinite revives.
4. Burn is good early on, but then it falls off a lot. Things like Critical on Burn that ups critical by 25% on a burning enemy makes it viable later, but at some point, you'd just rather use your combos for damage and burn for additional thicks and combos.
My best tips are to go through the skill trees and pictos skills and find out the best combos you want to use. There are so many broken and fun combos in this game, and you don't need to look online for them, they are easy to figure out.
Also, put this game on hard. It's challenging but not impossible. It's gonna make you try to min max your party at the stronger bosses.

snippet.textDisplay:
Huge leveling tip for early game!- 

After leaving gestral village you can go to the hidden gestral arena in the gold tree area nearby. You can solo fight four gestrals and get a pictos that buffs you if you fight solo. And they're BIG buffs. By equipping them all to someone you like and mastering the parry of the last fighter -small head guy, you can get 32k XP per fight with fight times of like 20 seconds. Also 1.3k currency per fight and rarely some weapon leveling stones. I'm level 45 and I just started act 2 and I solo every fight now haha it's funny
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm playing expert and was having a tough time for awhile then I found some arena where I could keep fighting a boss for a lot of xp. Ended up leveling up to 30 with maelle in like 30 minutes and 26 with others. I was only a few hours into the game. In any other turn based RPG it'd ruin the game and you'd be one shotting everything. In this game it kinda just makes you competitive but still takes takes a lot to win certain battles. This is pn expert though. 

Another tip I'd give is to explore higher level areas even if you see "Danger" just run past enemies, because you can find a lot of high level items early that will help a lot early game.

My favorite setup I've found is to abuse verso's HP differential attack. I pretty much just never heal him and don't really care if he dies bc I'll just revive him. Stack HP on him with stats and pictos then always have him on low HP and you can damage cap combo early. Meanwhile stack Maelle with HP/Def and any dmg reduction pictos or shell pictos so she pretty much is always alive to revive verso if needed. Plus she does really good damage anyway.

snippet.textDisplay: I did find that stacking DEF/VIT on Lune early made her an absolute shaman tank that can keep herself up even if Gustave goes down. The downside to these stats is they're only good if you're really bad at dodging. I'm still getting used to the timings so it's been a boon for now, but if you're able to completely mitigate damage through parry then these stats become useless. Gustave is just leaning heavy into LCK for me and his crit is around 35% with my current setup. Once he hits 50% it will be an absolute monster for damage. Wondering what the breaks are for these stats and if raw damage from might scales really well or not. Lots to dig through here.

snippet.textDisplay: Great video. A bit of expansion on the last point, the QTE option only affects your party's outgoing attacks. Meaning you won't have to react when your characters are doing their skills. You can just watch the animation and the QTEs will say "auto." However, this does not apply to dodging and parrying  incoming attacks. You still have to time those and react accordingly. If you're having trouble with dodging and parrying or are struggling, you can change the game's difficulty at any time.
snippet.textOriginal: Great video. A bit of expansion on the last point, the QTE option only affects your party's outgoing attacks. Meaning you won't have to react when your characters are doing their skills. You can just watch the animation and the QTEs will say "auto." However, this does not apply to dodging and parrying  incoming attacks. You still have to time those and react accordingly. If you're having trouble with dodging and parrying or are struggling, you can change the game's difficulty at any time.
